body.para: On April 19, 2002 02:13 pm, Eric E wrote:

quote.quotepara: The adaptiveness you're talking seem more general to me how many apps can you run at once, extra tray apps, etc., in addition to eye candy.

body.para: this is another part of the problem i didn't even bother getting into. depending on which apps you use and how you use them, certain look 'n feel settings cause more or less pain for the user.
you can't set the eye-candy-o-meter without a solid understanding of:
o the hardware at hand (CPU, video card, RAM, I/O speed) o the applications used and general usage patterns of that system o the user's personal quirks^H tastes
it deffinitely sounds like a job for some sort of agent software to me, and quite a sophisticated one at that.

quote.quotepara: Entirely true, and we all want to get there, but you're asking a team of volunteers to solve the next 50 years of HCI problems. Let's go a little slow here, man, even if we are just polishing railings instead of building new buildings.

body.para: agreed, completely. fix what is wrong with today, then work on tomorrow.

and even more importantly, instead of saying things should be perfect (yes,everyone would like to see kde be able to configure itself according to your desires which it picks up via ESP), provide concrete solutions. as in:
o here is the problem o here is the solution o here is an implementation
anything short of that is not useful.
